Award.AwardTitle: Third Workshop on an Open Knowledge Network: Building the National Semantic Information Infrastructure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This workshop engages a multidisciplinary community in a discussion about taking the initial steps in building an evolving Open Knowledge Network to encode all entities and the relationships among them, that would evolve continuously with new data and information. The OKN would thus be a fundamental building block in evolving the world-wide web to a new level of semantic understanding and application. The vision of such a knowledge graph is feasible given the availability of big data that are growing with time; advanced machine learning techniques that can aid in the creation of such a massive graph, and in its use; and, importantly, demonstration of the power of such knowledge graphs via extant commercial services such as Apple Siri; GoogleTalk; Amazon Alexa, and Microsoft Cortana. An Open Knowledge Network would enable a new generation of knowledge-rich intelligent applications and systems.

The workshop examines the applicability of this idea across multiple disciplines and applications domains. Experts from a wide range of disciplines, including biomedicine, medicine, geosciences, finance, and manufacturing, will discuss domain-specific issues as well as identify common approaches and common issues that cut across domains. The workshop will develop concrete steps to be taken to help realize the vision of OKN.

Natural interfaces to large knowledge structures have the potential to impact science, education and business to an extent comparable to the WWW. While the first wave of such technology is now available in consumer services such as Siri, GoogleTalk, Cortana and Alexa, these services are limited in their scope of knowledge; not open to direct access or to contributors beyond their corporate firewalls; and, able to answer only relatively limited questions in specific business domains. An open initiative of the type being proposed would allow for experimentation at scale across many user communities and would support research and innovation in academia, enable industry to experiment, and enable governments at various levels (local, state, federal) to create new services using Open Data. The vision for the proposed OKN is that it would aspire to be a listing of every known concept from the worlds of science, business, medicine and human affairs. It would include not just raw data, but semantic information in machine readable form. The architecture would allow contributors to encode the knowledge related to their topics of interest and, thus, connect that to the larger network, without having to go through so-called "gatekeepers". By providing an open service, OKN would enable the notion of "permission-less innovation." Indeed, an open resource like OKN may be in a better position to provide more trustworthy information/knowledge than proprietary, closed systems. The vision for creating such a common knowledge network resonates with the NSF Big Ideas of Harnessing the Data Revolution and Convergence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This meeting was the third in a series of workshops hosted by the NITRD Big Data Interagency Working Group to discuss the development of a national-scale semantic information infrastructure that has come to be called the Open Knowledge Network (OKN).

Participants agreed that an OKN with very large amounts of knowledge about entities in the world would result in the next wave of knowledge-powered artificial intelligence innovations with transformative impact ranging from scientific research to the commercial sector. Today, the US tech industry (Amazon, Apple, Facebook, Google, Microsoft and others) develop their own knowledge networks and find them a key technology for their businesses. However, their knowledge networks are proprietary and very expensive to build, so smaller businesses and other organizations (e.g., government, non-profits) do not have access to these powerful technologies. Knowledge graphs are also not accessible to academia, which hampers research advances needed by industry to push these technologies to deliver new future capabilities.

Developing the OKN as shared infrastructure would have a transformative impact in large businesses, small businesses, academia, and government, comparable to the Internet itself, that would result in significant innovation and economic growth.

Workshop discussions targeted four specific domains that demonstrate the vertical depth of capabilities of OKN. These domains were geosciences, health, finance, and manufacturing. They are considered the verticals of OKN. Crossing all these verticals is a horizontal layer of core capabilities and services shared by all domains.

Three major recommendations for immediate core capabilities in the horizontal aspects of OKN to demonstrate its power were:

  1. User-friendly (“Natural”) interfaces: Design and prototype natural language interfaces to OKN that would enable non-technical users to access data, information, and services available in OKN through voice queries.

  2. Query services: Design and prototype query servers that would enable access to OKN data and other content, including access involving simple reasoning.

  3. Integration services: Design and prototype integration servers that can access distributed resources of OKN under a single point of access.

Several recommendations were made to advance OKN in vertical application domains:

  1. Queries: Gather representative queries of interest in each domain, both from regular citizens (e.g., “what is the trend in air quality last month in Bethesda?”) and researchers (e.g., “find fisheries data for the last 50 years in the upper Hudson river”). This would enable their organization according to the capabilities they require, understanding which capabilities would require research advances, and exposing the connections between different domains (eg, health and environment, natural resources and manufacturing).

  2. Inventory: Compile an inventory of existing ontologies, data resources, services, and frameworks in a domain, using a shared representation that can be easily accessed. This would facilitate the understanding of existing resources in each domain.

  3. Seeding: Foster prototyping efforts of OKN in the community and encourage existing repositories to expose their data to seed OKN perhaps through extensions of the schema.org framework.

4. Connect: Foster connections across domains, which are currently largely disconnected and hard to cross-walk.

5. Metrics: Define objective measures of OKN use across different stakeholders, adoption of technology and vocabularies, and effectiveness to support growth with minimal effort.

Other general recommendations included: 1) growing the OKN community with the research, government and industry stakeholders, 2) developing and implementing curriculum for semantic technologies, and 3) considering the creation of a governance for OKN.
